Award.AwardTitle: Consortium for Advanced Manufacturing Foresights: Defining the Critical Needs of the Advanced Manufacturing Research Community
Award.AbstractNarration:
The revitalization of the U.S. advanced manufacturing industry requires that promising discoveries, innovations and inventions made in U.S. are matured and manufactured in the U.S. Achieving this goal requires the creation of a mechanism for identifying emerging advanced manufacturing technologies and maturing them through public-private investments in translational and interdisciplinary research and development. The Consortium for Advanced Manufacturing Foresights (Consortium) serves as a "think-and-do tank" to forecast which nascent technologies will most enable future U.S. leadership in advanced manufacturing by leveraging industry knowledge with federal investments in basic and applied research. Technologies will be prioritized based on economic impact, job growth, likely co-investment by the private sector, impact on multiple industry sectors, and the likelihood of the U.S. gaining a first-mover advantage. The Consortium will provide technology roadmaps and reports to the federal government outlining projections for technology development, application, and economic impacts. The Consortium will also identify and report on best practices in technology commercialization and workforce development to guide future investments. Outreach efforts will enhance public knowledge by conveying high-technology career opportunities in advanced manufacturing and the benefits of advanced manufacturing to the economic, energy, health and national security sectors.

The Consortium will: 1) Serve as a formal mechanism for soliciting input from across the broad manufacturing community and its supply chains to identify opportunities for federal investments in next generation advanced manufacturing technologies; 2) Convene national thought leaders to prioritize among nascent technologies 3) Articulate visions for aligning advanced manufacturing research, workforce development, and outreach with national priorities and challenges, and; 4) Ensure that key stakeholders and broader audiences are made aware of the criticality and the benefits of advanced manufacturing via an integrated communications strategy. The Leadership Council of the Consortium consists of 30 thought leaders across multiple industry sectors, academia, key manufacturing associations and think tanks representing over 30,000 manufacturing and technology experts. Identification of technologies will incorporate contextual search of publications, datasets and federal research programs and solicited input from industry experts, entrepreneurs, venture capital community, academic researchers and federal technology leaders. The Consortium will produce detailed reports on selected emerging technologies and provide responses to requests for information by federal agencies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
MForesight: The Alliance for Manufacturing Foresight was established in 2015 to strengthen the U.S manufacturing innovation ecosystem, to provide a continuous source of intelligence to public and private sector decision makers, aligning R&D opportunities with national priorities, and to serve as the voice of the nation?s advanced manufacturing community. Through a series of workshops, reports, national conferences, and regional roundtables, MForesight engaged the broad national manufacturing community, identified and disseminated detailed information on emerging technologies and cross-cutting challenges in advanced manufacturing, and highlighted long-term trends that have affected domestic production for better and worse.

 

True to its mission of serving as the voice of the national manufacturing community, well over 300 members of the manufacturing community contributed to MForesight reports and events, and over 2,000 leaders from industry, academia, non-governmental organizations, and federal and state government participated in MForesight activities. This work produced multiple reports that have been downloaded well over 60,000 times, as well as national summits, articles in widely read publications, and briefings to business, federal agencies, and Congressional leaders.

 

The results have been indisputable. In Washington and state capitols, the national conversation has shifted to recognize the importance of manufacturing and its centrality to innovation ecosystems that drive national and regional prosperity. Instead of dismissing manufacturing as a bygone activity with no place in the ?knowledge economy? policymakers are now debating specific steps to help rebuild American industry. Multiple legislative bills are being introduced, some with major initiatives to restructure federal agencies and spending priorities to ensure the long-term renaissance of U.S. manufacturing. Many of these incorporate ideas first articulated in MForesight reports and reinforced by MForesight in briefings and articles.

 

Addressing specific technical issues, MForesight?s work impacted federal spending and programmatic initiatives. By highlighting the issues facing manufacturers in the realm of cybersecurity, MForesight motivated the creation of a new Manufacturing USA institute. Solicitation for another institute, the Advanced Regenerative Medicine Institute, was also informed by MForesight?s report on ?Biomanufacturing Technologies for Regenerative Medicine.? Work on the evolving nature of manufacturing supply chains elevated the importance of domestic supplier availability, the competitive advantages of supply chain integration, and the challenges facing small and medium-sized manufacturers (SMMs) to perform in future manufacturing ecosystems. This report encouraged new efforts by state and federal programs to prepare SMMs for these changes. MForesight?s studies of advanced materials, specifically high-entropy alloys and metamaterials, highlighted investment needs in specific process technologies to scale promising discoveries and inventions and prompted new R&D efforts by federal agencies. MForesight also developed an education and training curriculum for hardware entrepreneurs, distributed manufacturing technologies to transition from ?making? to ?manufacturing? that influenced manufacturing education across the country and led the Department of Energy to create a new program called ?Build4Scale?. 

 

MForesight engaged the nation?s leading scientific and engineering experts to identify opportunities to advance new technologies that will give U.S. manufacturers global competitive advantage. Ideas Worth Scaling identified gaps in translational R&D needed to advance emerging technologies from lab to manufacturing including advanced materials and architectures. Challenges Worth Researching identified R&D roadmaps to address cross-cutting challenges such as cybersecurity for manufacturers, workforce development, and barriers to implementing smart manufacturing technologies.

 

MForesight?s work has also exploded the myth that the U.S. can continue to invent new technologies but manufacture them overseas. The last 20 years has shown indisputably that invention and innovation are not the same; that innovation is tightly linked to production and happens best where the factories are. Unfortunately, that is too often offshore. Not only has the U.S. lost its ability to innovate, it has also lost the ability to manufacture far too many products or to commercialize new ones. Recognizing this loss of manufacturing know-how, engineering talent, equipment producers, and comprehensive domestic supply chains is the critical first step in fixing the problem. MForesight shone a harsh spotlight that policymakers can no longer ignore.

 

Combined, new institutes, research programs, and policy initiatives that emerged from MForesight?s work have significantly changed the national environment for manufacturing. With continued implementation of recommendations made by MForesight, the nation will be far better positioned to restore its industrial competitiveness, lead the industries of the future, and rely on advanced manufacturing to rebuild broad-based national prosperity and security.
